timeline.subject: Jean Lallemand

prior_accusations.context: Named Jean Lallemand as accomplice while masked, before her execution

notable_quotes.speaker: Voiriat Jean Voiriat (witness 2)
notable_quotes.english: very small companion (threat to diminish him)
notable_quotes.context: Threat allegedly made by Jean Lallemand during lawsuits

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Lallemand to his wife
notable_quotes.french: Truye, ribaulde, reviens tu je pensois que le diable t'eut emporté
notable_quotes.english: Sow, ribald, have you returned, I thought the devil had taken you
notable_quotes.context: After wife's encounter with man in black

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Lallemand about bones/objects
notable_quotes.french: du mal que l'on avoit donné pour mettre divorse entre luy et sa femme, et qu'il les monteroit au maire de Moncel comme justice
notable_quotes.english: evil given to create divorce between him and his wife, and that he would show them to the mayor of Moncel as justice
notable_quotes.context: Explaining mysterious objects found in his coat

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Lallemand
notable_quotes.french: soit riche et puissant Sy estoit il aussy bien pour luy faire ung plaisir
notable_quotes.english: be rich and powerful, he was as well positioned to do him a favor
notable_quotes.context: Reference to opponent Demenge de Moncel

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Michiel Jeannel (witness 3)
notable_quotes.french: et qu'il faisoit ses choses secrettement
notable_quotes.english: and that he did his things secretly
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why he hadn't seen evidence despite being in the house often

notable_quotes.speaker: Diez Demenge Aubert (witness 37)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il luy cousteroit bien vingt cinq fois autant plus tost se mettroit il en guise de chat
notable_quotes.english: it would cost him twenty-five times as much, he would sooner put himself in the guise of a cat
notable_quotes.context: Threat to Mongeon Vallentin over sheep dispute

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacques Houllon (brother-in-law)
notable_quotes.french: au diable fut ce meschant homme qu'il ne leur avoit poinct apporté de chanse
notable_quotes.english: to the devil with this wicked man who brought them no luck
notable_quotes.context: After wall fell when Jean came to see it

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Babel (witness 33), quoting Jean
notable_quotes.french: qu'il estoit desormais vieulx et ne vivroit plus guieres
notable_quotes.english: that he was now old and would not live much longer
notable_quotes.context: Explaining why he didn't want to cut good timber in woods

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Lallemand under torture
notable_quotes.french: ce que les tesmongs en ont deposé estre par envye, et hayne qu'ilz ont contre luy a la sollicitation de sa partye adverse
notable_quotes.english: what the witnesses have testified is through envy and hatred they have against him at the solicitation of his opposing party

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean Lallemand under torture
notable_quotes.french: que ce sont choses controuvez par tesmoings acheptéz
notable_quotes.english: these are things contrived by bought witnesses

relationships.evidence_text: Were such close neighbours there was only a wall between them
Long reputation, and mother already suspected

economic_context.details: Jean Lallemand was doyen (tax collector) and had property disputes. Multiple legal cases over tithes (18 écus debt, cases with Jacques Hugo Vincent). Had meadow leased to Martin Fleurant as 'gaigeure' (pledge/security). Owned a mill. Described as having more property than his step-sister. Legal disputes over taxes and property seizures when he was doyen. Accusations of false testimony ('faux dismeur') in legal cases. Multiple accords/settlements suggest litigation-prone. Economic tensions central to accusations.

prior_legal_disputes.description: Beat Voiriat and called him thief

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a complex case with extensive legal history. Jean Lallemand appears to have been a relatively wealthy and litigious individual who owned property, a mill, and served as doyen (tax collector). The case is remarkable for several reasons: (1) Jean successfully obtained reparation from multiple people who called him witch BEFORE this trial; (2) He maintained his denial even under torture; (3) The Change de Nancy recommended release (renvoyé); (4) Evidence is heavily hearsay-based with many witnesses reporting general reputation or second-hand stories; (5) The alleged supernatural incidents (flying out chimney, man in black, mysterious bones) are all hearsay; (6) Direct evidence consists mainly of economic disputes over tithes, meadows, and property, with animal deaths following quarrels. The trial appears driven by the Vallentin family who initiated it, and many witnesses note Jean's litigiousness and success in obtaining legal settlements. The document notes 'marked tendency for court to lead witnesses by asking them questions' suggesting prosecutorial bias. Witness 20 (the servant) explicitly denied the stories attributed to her, calling them 'imposture.' Jean characterized witnesses as 'bought' and motivated by envy/hatred at instigation of his adversary. The economic_status assessment of 'comfortable' is based on: ownership of mill, multiple properties, ability to lease meadows, service as doyen, ability to pay legal settlements (18 écus), described as having more property than step-sister, described as 'riche et puissant' opponent. No indication of healing practices.
